Sentence: A skyscraper is in architecture as a boast is in interpersonal relations.
Author: Mason Cooley

Sentence: A committee is a cul-de-sac down which ideas are lured and then quietly strangled.
Author: Barnett Cocks

Sentence: As iron is eaten away by rust, so the envious are consumed by their own passion.
Author: Antisthene

Sentence: Reading is to the mind what exercise is to the body.
Author: Joseph Addison

Sentence: As cold waters to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a far country.
Author: The bible proverbs 25:25

Sentence: As soap is to the body, tears are to the soul.
Author: Yiddish proverb

Sentence: What garlic is to salad, insanity is to art.
Author: Augustus Saint-Gaudens

Sentence: The murals in restaurants are on a par with the food in museums.
Author: Peter de Vries

Sentence: Al Capone was to crime what J.P. Morgan was to Wall Street, the first man to exert national influence over his trade.
Author: Andrew Sinclair

Sentence: Prisons are to crime what greenhouses are to plants.
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Sentence: All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely player. They have their exits and entrances, and one man in his time plays many parts.
Author: Shakespear

Sentence: Books...are like lobster shells, we surround ourselves with them, then we grow out of them and leave them behind, as evidence of our earlier stage of development.
Author: Dorothy L. Slayers

Sentence: Novels are like wives;  you don't talk about them. But movies are different; they are like mistresses, and you can brag a bit.
Author: Anton Chekhov

Sentence: Medicine is my lawful wife and literature is my mistress; when I tire of one, I spend the night with the other.
Author: Anton Chekhov

Sentence: On the banks of the grey torrent of life, love is the only flower.
Having your book turned into a movie is like seeing your oxen turned into bouillon cubes.
Author: John Le Carr√©

Sentence: A prince who writes against flattery is as strange as a pope who writes against infallability.
Author: Voltaire

Sentence: The man who loves other countries as much as his own stands on a level with the man who loves other women as much as  he loves his own wife.
Author: Theodore Roosevelt

Sentence: Ideas are lie arrows, but there has to be a bow. And politics is the bow of idealism.
Author: Bill Moyers

Sentence: Washington D.C. is to lying what Wisconsin is to cheese.
Author: Dennis Miller

Sentence: A definition is the enclosing a wilderness of idea within a wall of words.
Author: Samuel Butler

Sentence: Romance has been elegantly defined as the offspring of fiction and love.
Author: Isaac D'Israeli

Sentence: Love is a net that catches hearts like a fish.
Author: Muhammad Alo

Sentence: Every person's work, whether it be literature or music or pictures or architecture or anything else, is always a portraint of that person.
Author: Samuel Butler

S2: the hand that is dealt you
Sentence: Life is like a game of cards. The hand that is dealt you represents determinism.
Author: Jawaharlal Nehru

Sentence: Life is a great tapestry. The individual is only an insignificant thread in an immense and miraculous pattern.
Sports is the toy department of life.
Author: chapter title

Sentence: A film director is not a creator, but a midwife. His business is to deliver the actor of a child that he did not know he had within him.
Author: Jean Renoir

Sentence: Patriotism is in political life what faith is in religion.
Author: John Dahlberg

Sentence: Asking an incumbent member of the congress to vote for term limits is a bit like asking a chicken to vote for Colonel Sanders.
Author: Bob Inglis

T1: the president of the United States
Sentence: The president of the United States bears about as much relationship to the real business of running America as does the Colonel Sanders to the business of frying chicken.
Author: J.G. Ballard

Sentence: A group of politicians deciding to dump a President because his morals are bad is like the Mafia getting together to bump off the Godfather for not going to the church.
Author: Russell Baker

Sentence: Nationalism is an infantile disease. It is the measles of mankind.
Author: Albert Einstein

Sentence: Power will intoxicate the best hearts, as wine the strongest heads.
Author: Charles Caleb Colton

Sentence: Anger is a wind which blows out the lamp of the mind.
Author: Robert G. Ingersoll

Sentence: Automn is a second spring when every leaf is a flower.
Author: Albert Camus

Sentence: Despair is vinegar from the wine of hope.
Author: Austin O'malley

Sentence: The dance is a poem of which each movement is a word.
Author: Mata Hari

Sentence: Egotism is the anesthetic that dulls the pain of stupidity.
Author: Frank Leahy

Sentence: Feedback is the breakfast of champions.
Author: Ken Blanchard & Spencer Johnson

Sentence: Music is the wine that fills the cup of silence.
Author: Robert Fripp

Sentence: Vulgarity is the garlic in the salad of charm.
Author: Cyrill Connolly

Sentence: Zeal is a volcano, on the peak of which the grass of indecisiveness does not grow.
Author: Kahlil Gibran

Sentence: Alcohol is the anesthesia by which we endure the operation of life.
Author: George Bernard Shaw

Sentence: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
Author: Carl Jung

T1: caresses, expressions of one sort or another
Sentence: Caresses, expressions of one sort or another, are necessary to the life of the affections, as leaves are to the life of a tree. I they are wholly restrained, love will die at the roots.
Author: Nathaniel Howthorne

Sentence: A man has every season, while a woman has only the right to spring.
Author: Jane Fonda

Sentence: A man who discovers a woman's weakness is like the huntsman in the heat of the day who finds a cool spring. He wallows in it.
Author: Jean Giraudoux

Sentence: Giving a man space is like giving a dog a computer: the chances are he will not use it wisely.
Author: Bette-Jane Raphael

Sentence: The great majority of men, especially in France, both desire and possess a fashionable woman, much in the way one might own a fine horse - as a luxury befitting a young man.
Author: Stendhal

Sentence: Man is the hunter; woman is the game.
Author: Alfred, Lord Tennyson

Sentence:
As the moon retains her nature,
though darkness spread itself before her face as a curtain,
so the Soul remains perfect
even in the bosom of the fool.
Author: Akhenaton

Sentence: A man is not necessarily intelligent because he has plenty of ideas, any more that he is a good general because he has plenty of soldiers.
Author: Nicolas Chamfort

Sentence: To most men, experience is like the stern lights of a ship which illumine only the track it has passed.
Author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

Sentence: Global warning might be a fever the earth is running in an attempt to ward off a deadly infection known as homo sapiens.
Author: Rick Bayan

Sentence: Actors are the jockeys of literature. Other supply the horses, the plays, and we simply make them run
Author: Ralph Ridchardson

Sentence: Faith is the oasis of the heart, which will never be reached by the caravan of thinking.
Author: Kahlil Gibran

Sentence: Giving money and power to government is like giving whiskey and car to teenage boys.
Author: O' Rourke

Sentence: America is an enormous frosted cupcake in the middle of millions of starving people
Author: Gloria Steinem

Sentence: Art is the sex of imagination
Author: George Jean Nathan

Sentence: Worry is interest paid on trouble before it falls due
Author: W.R. Inge

Sentence: The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only one page.
Author: St Augustine

Sentence: Art at its most significant is a Distant Early Warning System that can always be relied on to tell the old culture what is beginning to happen to it.
Author: Marshall Mcluhan

Sentence: Books are like imprisonned souls till someone takes them down from a shelf and frees them.
Author: Samuel Butler

Sentence: Puns are a three-way Circus of words : [..] words thrusting their heads into the mouths of lions.
Author: Richard Lederer

Sentence: Critics are like pigs in a pastry cart.
Simile is the most familiar of all literary embellishments, in a class with a wedge of lemon or a sprig of parsley. It can raise a cupcake to the level of a petit four.
Author: James J. Kilpatrick

Sentence: Unsolicited advice is the junkmail of life.
Fame is a fickle food upon a shifting plate.
Author: Emily Dickinson

Sentence: Our birthdays are feathers in the broad wing of time.
Author: Jean Paul Richter

Sentence: Tears are the safety valve of the heart when too much pressure is led on it.
Author: Albert Smith

Sentence: A quarrel between friends, when made up, adds a new tie to friendship, as experience shows that the callosity formed round a broken bone makes it stronger than before
Author: St, Francis de Sales

Sentence: Life is a hospital in which every patient is possessed by the desire of changing his bed. One would prefer to suffer near the fire, and another is certain he would get well if he were by the window.
Author: Charles Baudelaire

Sentence: Life loves to be taken by the lapel and told, "I am with you kid, lets go."
Author: Maya Angelou

Sentence: Life is a moderately good play with a badly written third act.
Author: Truman Capote.

Sentence: Society is like a stew. If you don't stir it up every once in a while, then a layer of scum floats to the top.
Author: Edward Abbey

Sentence: I make all my decisions on intuition. I throw a spear into the darkness, that is intuition.
Author: Ingmar Bergman

Sentence: Money is the mother's milk of politics.
Author: Jesse Unruh

Sentence: My movements to the chair of Government will be accompanied by feelings not unlike those of a culprit who is going to the place of his execution.
Author: George Washington

Sentence: Written laws are like spiders' webs, and will, like them, only entangle and hold the poor and weak [...].
Author: Anacharsis

Sentence: Written laws are like spiders' webs [...] the rich and powerful will easily break through them.
Author: Anacharsis

Sentence: Laws are like cobwebs, it may catch small flies.
Author: Jonathan Swift

Sentence: Laws are like cobwebs, it lets wasps and hornets break through.
Author: Jonathan Swift

Sentence: Politics is the womb in which war develops.
Author: Karl Von Clausewitz

Sentence: A man's action is only a picture book of his creed.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Sentence: Adventure is the champain of life.
Author: G. K. Chesterton

Sentence: The adjective is the banana peel of the part of speech.
Author: Clifton Fadiman

Sentence: Modern English is the Wal-Mart of languages: convenient, huge, hard to avoid, superficially friendly, and devouring all rivals in its eagerness.
Author: Mark Abley

Sentence: An apology is the super glue of life. It can repair just about anything.
Author: Lynn Johnston

Sentence: Doctrine is nothing but the skin of truth set up and stuffed.
Author: Henry Ward Beecher

Sentence: Chaos is the score upon which reality is written.
Author: Henry Miller

Sentence: Courage is the ladder on which other virtues mount.
Author: Clare Booth Luce

Sentence: The dew of compassion is a tear.
Author: Lord Byron

Sentence: Compromise makes a good umbrella, but a poor roof.
Author: James Russell Lowell

Sentence: The dress is the vase which the body follow.
Author: Pierre Cardin

Sentence: Failure is the condiment that gives success its flavor.
Author: Truman Capote

Sentence: The flower is the poetry of reproduction.
Author: Jean Giraudoux

Sentence: Freedom is the oxygen of the soul.
Author: Moshe Dayan

Sentence: Genius is a promontory jutting out into the infinite.
Author: Victor Hugo

Sentence: Habit is a cable; we weave a thread of it each day, and at last we cannot break it.
Author: Horace Mann

Sentence: Procrastination is the thief of time.
Author: Edward Young

Sentence: Poverty is the mother of crime.
Author: Marcus Aurelius

Sentence: A proverb is anonymous human history compressed to the size of a seed.
Author: Stefan Kanfer

Sentence: Peanut butter is the pat√© for children.
Author: Brigitte Bardot

Sentence: If I were to personally define religion, I would say that it is a bandage that man has invented to protect a soul made bloody by circumstance.
Author: Theodore Dreiser

Sentence: A riot is at bottom the language of the unheard.
Author: Martin Luther King, Jr

Sentence: Scientists are peeping toms at the keyhole of eternity.
Author: Arthur Koestler

Sentence: Skepticism is the chastity of the intellect.
Author: George Santayana

Sentence: Thought is the seed of action.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Sentence: Virtue is the beauty of the soul
Author: Socrates

Sentence: A word is a bud attempting to become a twig.
Author: Gaston Bachelard

Sentence: Life is like riding a bicycle. To keep your balance you must keep moving.
Author: Albert Einstin

Sentence: Life is like a ten-speed bicycle. Most of us have gears we never use.
Author: Charles M. Schulz

Sentence: A face is too slight a foundation for happiness.
Author: Mary Wortley Montagu

Sentence: Glances are the heavy artillery of the flirt: everything can be conveyed in a look, yet that look can always be denied, for it cannot be quoted word for word.
Author: Stendhal

Sentence: Prejudice is the psoriasis of the human condition: it's unsightly and it never completely vanishes, but with a little care we can keep it under control.
Author: Rick Bayan

Sentence: No fathers or mothers think their own children ugly; and this self-deceit is yet stronger with respect to the offspring of the mind.
Author: Miguel de Cervantes

Sentence: There are some people who leave impression not so lasting as the imprint of an oar upon the water.
Author: Kate Chopin

Sentence: Criticism may not be agreeable, but it is necessary, It fulfills the same function as pain in the human body. It calls attention to an unhealthy state of things.
Author: Winston Chirchill

Sentence: When you get back together with an old boyfriend, it's pathetic. It's like having a garage sale and buying your own stuff back.
Author: Laura Kightlinger

Sentence: Everything that reminds me of her goes through me like a spear.
Author: John Keats

Sentence: An election is coming. Universal peace is declared, and the foxes have a sincere interest in prolonging the lives of the poultry.
Author: George Eliot

Sentence: An exageration is a truth that has lost its temper.
Author: Kahlil Gibran

Sentence: A man... should keep his friendship in constant repair.
Author: Dr Samuel Johnson

Sentence: One of those involuntary revealing thoughts one surprises, running like a rat through the muck-heap of my mind: Maybe I'll be able to afford that ikon if he goes.
Author: Friend, Donald

Sentence: Her mind was as full of religion as a night sky is full of things visible and invisible. She left the man and took his religion and became a nun in the course of time.
Author: Spark, Muriel

Sentence:
Your mind now, mouldering like wedding-cake
heavy with useless experience, rich
with suspicion, rumor, fantasy,
crumbling to pieces under the knife-edge
of mere fact.
Author: Rich, Adrienne

Sentence: Everything spun around him; then his mind blanked, like a TV suddenly switched off.
Author: Jerzy N. Kosinski

Sentence: The mind works like a prism, and when a ray of light enters the prism it is divided into seven colors. Mind is a prism and reality is divided through it.
Author: Osho

Sentence: Mind contemplating mind is like an object and its shadow--the object cannot shake the shadow off. The two are one.
Author: Thich Nhat Hanh

Sentence: The discipline tying mind in that way to the meditative object is expressed by the simile of training an elephant, for example, a wild elephant is tied with many massive cords to a trunk or a post.
Author: ‚Äî Wayman, Alex

Sentence: Like trees similar in their gross physical profile, brains can be similar in their gross functional profiles while being highly idiosyncratic in the myriad details of their fine-grained arborization.
Author: Churchland, Paul

Sentence: Just as a cake recipe requires you to use flour, sugar, and baking powder in the right amounts, your brain needs a fine chemical balance.
Author: ‚Äî Anonymous

Sentence: Cultivated ground has few weeds; a mind occupied by lawful business, has little room for useless regret.
Author: Johnson, Samuel (1709-1784)

S2: ethereal peak of a snow-clad mount
Sentence: These charges, at first held in constant mind, from Theseus slipped away as clouds are impelled by the breath of the winds from the ethereal peak of a snow-clad mount.
Author: ‚Äî Gaius Valerius Catullus (c. 84 - c. 54 B.C.)

Sentence: Corn is cleansed with the wind, and the soul with chastning.
Author: ‚Äî Ray [formerly Wray], John (1627-1705)

Sentence: Thus Vice and Virtue do my Soul divide,  Like a Ship tost between the Wind and Tide.
Author: Arwaker, Edmund (c.1655-1730)

T1: fleeting sleep loss we sometimes experience
S1: snowstorm's disrupting a single day of trash pickup
Sentence: The difference between the kind of fleeting sleep loss we sometimes experience and the chronic deprivation is like the difference between a snowstorm's disrupting a single day of trash pickup and a prolonged strike. No longer quite as easy to fix, and even when the strike is over, there's likely to be some stray debris floating around for quite some time yet."
Author: Konnikova, Maria (b. 1984)

Sentence:
Just as the ties recur beneath his train, dreams underlie
his rushing brain.
Author: ‚Äî Bishop, Elizabeth (1911-1979)

Sentence:
Like the notes of an old violin,
Thoughts talk to me within
My mind, that shuttered room
Author: ‚Äî Sassoon, Siegfried (1886-1967)

Sentence: Research explains why forgetting delivers this memory boost. Memories don't fly out of our brains like sparrows from a barn.
Author: Boser, Ulrich

Sentence: Further, just as the human stomach -- unlike the termite's -- can't digest wood, so there are some things our brains just aren't capable of knowing.
Author: Kaplan, Eric

Sentence: The upper part of the skull had been removed, and the exposed edge covered in layer after layer of gauze, completely saturated with blood, forming a funnel down into the interior of the cranium. The brain was gently pulsating within. It resembled a small animal in a grotto.
Author: Knausgaard, Karl Ove (b. 1968)

Sentence: Books live in the mind like honey inside a beehive.
Author: McGrath, Campbell (b. 1962)

Sentence: "His mind snagged on the word like a fish on a hook."
Author: Nicholls, David (b. 1966)

Sentence: I sometimes fancy that various archetypal situations circled tirelessly in Hitchcock's mind, like whales in a tank at the zoo.
Author: Ebert, Roger (1942-2013)

Sentence: It was hard enough to rescue himself from the avalanche of his own feelings, without allowing the gloomy St Bernard of his attention to wander into other fields.
Author: Edward St. Aubyn (b. 1960)

Sentence: Heroin landed purring at the base of his skull, and wrapped itself darkly around his nervous system, like a black cat curling up on its favourite cushion.
Author: Edward St. Aubyn (b. 1960)

Sentence: Just as birds are lifted up into the air by their feathers and can remain wherever they wish, the soul in the body is elevated by thought and spreads its wings everywhere.
Author: Offill, Jenny (b. 1968)

Sentence: I tried to think what I had loved knives for, but my mind slipped from the noose of the thought and swung, like a bird, in the center of empty air.
Author: Plath, Sylvia (1932-1963)

Sentence: And yet the rage that one felt was an abstract, undirected emotion which could be switched from one object to another like the flame of a blowlamp.
Author: Orwell, George

Sentence: I stored the fact that there were real glasses in the corner of my mind the way a squirrel stores a nut.
Author: Plath, Sylvia

Sentence: Delicious recollections float like perfume through the memory.
Author: Rich, Adrienne

Sentence: Words came without volition, sinking very slowly through his mind like pebbles.
Author: Murdoch, Iris

Sentence: My brain hurt like a warehouse, it had no room to spare; / I had to cram so many things to store everything in there.
Author: Bowie, David

Sentence: Mysteries are the food of the mind, and all the fundamental mysteries are necessary to sanity.
Author: Richards, I.A.

Sentence: In the preceding months he had prepared himself with meticulous care, filling his mind with distilled knowledge, drop by drop, until, on the eve of the first paper (Old English Set Texts) it was almost brimming over.
Author: Lodge, David

Sentence: Marsall McLuhan's ideas are Turkish baths of the mind.
Author: Bell, Daniel

Sentence: The picture which holds traditional philosophy captive is that of the mind as a great mirror, containing various representations--some accurate, some not--and capable of being studied by pure, non-empirical methods.
Author: Rorty, Richard

Sentence: Language is the express image and picture of human thoughts; and, from the picture, we may often draw very certain conclusions with regard to the original.
Author: ‚Äî Reid, Thomas (1710-1796)

Sentence: Thoughts in my head just come and go and change shape like the clouds.
Author: ‚Äî Levy, Andrea (b. 1956)

Sentence: Those final sounds, however, are nothing like the wind moving through the vacancy of a mind.
Author: ‚Äî Rankine, Claudia (b. 1963)

Sentence: The drug hit him like an express train, a white-hot column of light mounting his spine from the region of his prostate,
Author: ‚Äî Gibson, William (b. 1948)

Sentence: The only palliative is to keep the clean sea breeze of the centuries blowing through our minds, and this can be done only be reading old books.
Author: ‚Äî Lewis, C. S. (1898-1963)

T1: feeling of relation moving to its term
T2: some substantive thing, usually the last word we were pronouncing
Sentence: As a snowflake-crystal caught in the warm hand is no longer a crystal but a drop, so, instead of catching the feeling of relation moving to its term, we find we have caught some substantive thing, usually the last word we were pronouncing, statically taken, and with its function, tendency and particular meaning in the sentence quite evaporated.
Author: ‚Äî James, William (1842-1910)

Sentence:
Silently we went round and round, 
And through each hollow mind
The Memory of dreadful things
Rushed like a dreadful wind,
And Horror stalked before each man,
And Terror crept behind.
Author: Wilde, Oscar Fingal O'Flahertie Wills (1854-1900)

Sentence: Religion, ethics, metaphysics ‚Äì these are merely the 'spiritual' and 'inner' festivals of human anguish, ways of channelling the black waters of anxiety ‚Äì and towards what abyss?
Author: ‚Äî Lefebvre, Henri (1901-1991)

Sentence: The Great Depression had entered our souls like fog.
Author: ‚Äî Justice, Donald (1925-2004)

Sentence: Deep in the night, those warnings scuttle around my mind like rats.
Author: ‚Äî Kennedy, Pagan (b. 1963)

Sentence: The body [...] activates the senses, setting them to the frequencies at which the signals of new dangers can be received. Those signals appear as noise to the previous -- pre-war -- mind, as a breakdown in communication. The new mind, which the body floods with adrenaline, begins -- like a rabbit in a forest of foxes -- to decode all the signals, even if it's not capable of fitting them into any narrative.
Author: Hemon, Aleksandr (b. 1964)

Sentence: We've got this perverse situation in which the vast analytic powers of the entire world are being spent trying to understand a guy whose thoughts are often just six fireflies beeping randomly in a jar.
Author: Brooks, David (b. 1961)

Sentence: But if I can identify the lizard of envy crawling around in my psyche, I can usually tamp down the ire.
Author: Marino, Gordon

Sentence: Memory, a jar of flies. Spin off the lid.
Author: Seibles, Tim (b. 1955)

Sentence: Open our skulls, look in with a penlight, and you'll find an odd museum of ideas: sentences of history or mathematics remembered from school textbooks (no boy remembers his schooling like one who was taken out of school, let me assure you), sentences about politics read in a newspaper while wait...
Author: Adiga, Aravind (b. 1974)

Sentence:
Like an oyster
That cloisters a spoil of pearls, 
Untouched‚Äî 
The heart that‚Äôs had 
Enough
Stays shut.
Author: Essbaum, Jill Alexander

Sentence: A soul was like a worm in an apple, my mother told me.
Author: Offill, Jenny (b. 1968)

Sentence: In the years that followed he set about replenishing his mind, but it was never quite the same. The sense of purpose was lacking--there was no great Reckoning against which he could hoard his knowledge, so that it tended to leak away as fast as he acquired it.
Author: Lodge, David

Sentence: The mind may be pregnant "with some new theme"
Author: ‚Äî Cowper, William (1731-1800)

Sentence: When the mind is in a calm, our advice may saile over it with ease; but in a raging tempest the best admonitions run upon a desperate rock.
Author: ‚Äî Tubbe, Henry (1618-1655)

Sentence:
He finds no Tempest in his Mind,  
Fears no Billow, feels no Wind: 
All is serene, and quiet there.
Author: ‚Äî Flatman, Thomas (1635-1688)

Sentence: For a long time I locked the memories away in a room in my mind. I would sometimes touch the door, to make sure it was secure.
Author: ‚Äî Armeni, Damon T.

Sentence: Oh what a Tempest have I in my Stomach?
why, why, why did I have to spend hours doing this? In the red glare of the digital clock, my brain rattled its cage. I prepared for a wave of lunacy.
Author: Kennedy, Pagan (b. 1963)

Sentence: But I didn't want to linger, nor could I perhaps, for the sensation lasted only a few moments, then my brain sank its claws into it and I went back to the kitchen where everything was as I had left it, except for the color of the drinks, which were shiny and full of small, grayish bubbles now.
Author: Knausgaard, Karl Ove (b. 1968)

Sentence: The swing of the pendulum has finally shattered the myth, like a bull through a cobweb.
Author: Anon.

Sentence: If wits were pins, the man would be a veritable hedgehog.
Author: Fly by Night, Frances Hardinge

Sentence: You are the thunder and I am the lightning.
Author: Selena Gomez, Antonina Armato, Tim James, Devrim Karaoglu

Sentence: You are the sunshine of my life.
Author: Stevie Wonder

Sentence: But we refuse to believe that the bank of justice is bankrupt. We refuse to believe that there are insufficient funds in the great vaults of opportunity of this nation.
Author: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Sentence: Monetarism is to economics what christian science is to medicine.
In a shuttered room I roast Like a pumpkin in a serra
Author: Dylan Thomas

T1: woman after twenty years of romance
T2: woman after twenty years of marriage
Sentence: Twenty years of romance make a woman look like a ruin; but twenty years of marriage make her something like a public puilding.
Author: Oscar Wilde

Sentence: The Marxist analysis has got nothing to do with what happened in Stalin's Russia; it's like blaming Jesus Chirs for the Inquisition in Spain.
Author: Tony Benn

Sentence: Her sharp mind, sawing raggedly through illusion like a bread knife through a hunk of frozen fish.
Author: Fay Weldon

Sentence: The great nations have always acted like gangsters and the small nations like prostitutes.
Author: Stanley Kubrick

Sentence: A woman needs a man like a goldfish needs a motorbike.
Author: Anon.

Sentence: The sun was a toddler insistently refusing to go to bed: It was past eight-thirty and still light.
Author: John Green

Sentence: All religions, arts and sciences are branches of the same tree.
Author: Albert Einstein

Sentence: The photographer is like the cod, which produces a million eggs in order that one may reach maturity.
The vice-presidency is sort of like the last cookie on the plate. Everybody insists he won't take it, but somebody always does.
Author: Bill Vanghan

Sentence: Publishing a volume of verse is like droping a rose petal down the Grand Canyon and waiting for the echo.
Author: Don Marquis

Sentence: His ears make him look like a taxicab with both doors open.
Author: Howard Hughes of Clark Gable

Sentence: His ears are like the handles of a Greek amphora.
Author: P. G. Wodehouse

Sentence: Monarchy is like a splendid ship with all sails set; it moves majestically on, then it hits a rock and sink forever.
Author: Fisher Ames
